gov.nasa.larcfm.Util

Class LatLonAlt

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.nasa.larcfm.Util.LatLonAlt

  • public final class LatLonAlt
extends java.lang.Object
    Container to hold a latitude/longitude/altitude position

      • linear

        public LatLonAlt linear(Velocity v,
                        double time)
        Perform a linear projection of the current Position with given velocity and time. A great circle route is followed and the velocity represents the initial velocity along the great circle. Reminder: If this is used in a stepwise fashion over lat/lon, be careful when passing over or near the poles and keep the velocity track in mind.
        Parameters:
        v - the velocity
        time - the time from the current point Note: using a negative time value is the same a velocity moving in the opposite direction (along the great circle, if appropriate)
        Returns:
        linear projection of the position

      • linearEst

        public LatLonAlt linearEst(double dn,
                           double de)
        Compute a new lat/lon that is offset by dn meters north and de meters east. This is a computationally fast estimate, and only should be used for relatively short distances.
        Parameters:
        so - original lat/lon position
        dn - offset in north direction (m)
        de - offset in east direction (m)
        Returns:

      • linearEst

        public LatLonAlt linearEst(Velocity vo,
                           double tm)
        Compute a new lat/lon that is obtained by moving with velocity vo for tm secs This is a computationally fast estimate, and only should be used for relatively short distances.
        Parameters:
        so - original lat/lon position
        vo - velocity away from original position
        tm - time of relocation
        Returns:
        new lat/lon position in direction v0

      • toStringDecimalMinutes

        public java.lang.String toStringDecimalMinutes(int precision)
        Provide a string representation of this object in the 'Degree, Decimal Minutes' convention. Example: 39 degrees, 20.01 minutes north latitude, 85 degrees, 10.53 minutes west longitude is represented as N392001W0851053 (with a precision = 2)
        Parameters:
        precision - number of digits of precision for the decimal minutes.
        Returns:
        the string representation

      • parseDecimalMinutes

        public static LatLonAlt parseDecimalMinutes(java.lang.String name)
        parse the lat/lon from the name assuming the degrees, decimal minutes representation
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:

      • parse

        public static LatLonAlt parse(java.lang.String str)
        This parses a space or comma-separated string as a LatLonAlt (an inverse to the toString method). If three bare values are present, then it is interpreted as deg/deg/ft. If there are 3 value/unit pairs then each values is interpreted with regard to the appropriate unit. If the string cannot be parsed, an INVALID value is returned.

      • normalize

        public static LatLonAlt normalize(double lat,
                                  double lon,
                                  double alt)
        Normalizes the given latitude and longitude values to conventional spherical angles. Thus values over the pole (95 degrees of latitude) convert to 85 degrees and the longitude 180 degrees different.
        Parameters:
        lat - latitude
        lon - longitude
        alt - altitude
        Returns:
        normalized LatLonAlt value

      • normalize

        public static LatLonAlt normalize(double lat,
                                  double lon)
        Normalizes the given latitude and longitude values to conventional spherical angles. Thus values over the pole (95 degrees of latitude) convert to 85 degrees and the longitude 180 degrees different. The altitude is assumed to be zero.
        Parameters:
        lat - latitude
        lon - longitude
        Returns:
        normalized LatLonAlt value

      • normalize

        public LatLonAlt normalize()
        Creates a new LatLonAlt object from the current LatLonAlt object so that latitude and longitude values are conventional spherical angles. Thus values over the pole (95 degrees of latitude) convert to 85 degrees and the longitude 180 degrees different.
        Returns:
        normalized LatLonAlt value

      • isWest

        public boolean isWest(LatLonAlt a)
        Return true if this point is (locally) west of the given point.
        Parameters:
        a - reference point
        Returns:
        true if this point is to the west of the reference point within a hemisphere they share.
